Amplified slightly. Recorded using Tascam DR-05x recorder from woodland in late summer/early autumn. Mimicry of Oystercatcher amongst other species most audible in this - it was recorded to test out how accurate it' oystercatcher mimicry was (extremely accurate!)

**Comments**: None. 

**Recording modifications**: No edits. Recorded using Olympus LS-P1.

**Habitat (inc. vegetation and level)**: A path with forest on one, and fields on the other side. Bird singing from the top of a dead tree.

**Behaviour**: Singing while perched.

**Sex (with ID cues)**: None.

**Weather and other conditions**: Rainy morning.

**Comments on other birds**: Common blackbird singing and common wood pigeon cooing throughout. Occasional coos or song of collared doves, or yellowhammers respectively.
HP Filter 1500Hz, -12dB, Telinga Pro 5 + Mixpre 3
Recorded on a Tascam DR-05X

recordings.loc: Krötenweiher, near Thaining, Landsberg am Lech, Oberbayern, Bayern
recordings.file-name: XC473193-SINGDROSSEL, Trillermotiv  6.04.2019  Krötenweiher vor Thaining  6_01  VOC_190406-7414.mp3
recordings.rmk:
short cut of  XC473190. This Song Thrush begins his very first early morning song in the  darkness, when the Tawny Owl still is calling. And I wonder, why the Grey Heron sreeched like that.
 In this regio there are some Song Thrushes, who sing a special warbing (Triller) motive, which I didn't hear in other regios; may be it is the development of a dialect. But this warbling Thrush tops them all with ist often repeated  extraordinally long and intensive warbling.

recordings.loc: Krötenweiher, near Thaining, Landsberg am Lech, Oberbayern, Bayern
recordings.file-name: XC473190-SINGDROSSEL , Trillermotiv  6.04.2019   Kötenweiher Th.  6_01  VOC_190406-7414  g..mp3
recordings.rmk:
after some seconds of waiting, the Song Thrush begins his very first early morning song, still in the  darkness. In this regio there are some Song Thrushes, who sing a special warbing (Triller) motive, which I didn't hear in other regios; may be it is the development of a dialect. But this warbling Thrush tops them all with its often repeated  extraordinally long and intensive warbling. 
Another remarkable motive he sings in 02:09, 05:27, 07:55, 10:47.

Evening song from a Song Thrush on Inishbofin.  Over the first five seconds (before the first notes from the Song Thrush) the thin 'seep' calls are made by a Meadow Pipit. During, roughly, the last seven years, Inishbofin's Song Thrush  population has increased spectacularly - because nest-robbing Magpies have been removed.  One measure of the current Song Thrush density can be gauged by there being two other songsters in the background of this clip (although one is hard to discern).  Another local phenomenon is the incorporation of a Greenshank imitation into the song. One bird began this in the early spring of 2017, after a vocal Greenshank wintered within earshot of local Song Thrushes, and the habit spread across most of the island. Greenshank imitations can be heard at 0:14 and 0:43. Although the Greenshank imitation is delivered as a full-volume component, other imitations of other species are very quiet. Indeed, some are virtually inaudible until picked up by a recording device. In the clip, it is possible to hear an imitation of Common Snipe from 0:36 (five repeats over the next two seconds) and Arctic Tern at 0:46 and 0:49. In fact, I have heard more than one Song Thrush utter imitations of Common Snipe and Arctic Tern that were clearly audible - but I have not yet managed to record them.

The full story of how one of Inishbofin's Song Thrushes incorporated a Greenshank impersonation into its song that, through being overheard, was then copied by other Song Thrushes, is contained in this Facebook post : 

https://www.facebook.com/anthonymcgeehan/photos/a.167573230037133/1216759651785147/?type=3&theater
Tascam DR05 and Wildtronics parabole

Song from an adult Song Thrush (aged because the bird was in full view and allowed scrutiny of the relevant part of the wing to determine its age).  Apart from the Song Thrush, the only other easily discernible calls are monosyllabic notes interjected by a House Sparrow, such as at 0:02, 0:06 and 0:09.  Sometimes I notice that  Song Thrushes on Inishbofin (at least fifteen singing males since around 2014, previously just two during 2007-2012 when the the species suffered severe nest predation from Magpies ... since removed) do not indulge in as much 'overt' repetition as I hear from Song Thrushes in eastern Ireland.  Nonetheless, repetition is a hallmark of Inishbofin Song Thrushes too (a typical example is the four repetitions starting just before 0:18) but it can be less obvious. By this I mean that the repeated note may be less ear-catching because it is a high note or a note that is not especially strident - or because the songster intersperses a different note during a repeated sequence, thereby 'masking'  the repeated series. An example of a rogue note breaking up a sequence can be heard after 0:46 where two high notes are repeated but are then followed with a different note (the bird drops the pitch to create this note)  before it repeats the original high note for a third time. Note: the full sequence of two high notes, the dropped note, then the same high note again, is contained with a short space of just two seconds, from the 46th to the 48th second.

Song Thrushes are likely to generate a few bars of song  in late autumn or early winter. Mistle Thrushes do the same, although not as often. Weather conditions underpin the activity. In my experience, the air has to be still before any individual delivers a broadcast. So far, I have not managed to determine the age of a winter singer. I suspect that mainly young males are 'practicing'. Any that I have listened to are far from accomplished - a fact that would support them being apprentices.  Because the sex organs (gonads) of birds are dormant until lengthening daylight in January causes them to regrow, there would appear to be no serious courtship intent in a male's song before, say, Christmas. Although Song Thrushes are well known for breeding early - a few pairs often nest in late January - it is hard to imagine that pre-Christmas song would cut much ice with a female, especially as, in biological terms, she would be unresponsive to a male's overtures.  However, I don't know enough on the topic to comment. Basically, logic points to song during late autumn and before Christmas being rehearsal attempts of young males.  

As well as the Song Thrush, the ticking of a Robin is clear from the outset. In fact, a second Robin can be heard ticking in response to the first Robin. After 0:28, both can be heard 'trading ticks'.  Among the Song Thrush's vocals, there are possibly two examples of mimicry of Blackbird alarms: fleetingly at 0:59 and 1:53.  On a few occasions, the high-pitched 'tix' contact note of Song Thrush can be distinguished. It is quite tricky to pick out. The best examples are at 3:10 and 3:14. Goldfinches are obvious at 1:12 and a Wren sings at 2:45 (the first of three verses - answered by a neighbouring Wren in the background), then moves away to a nearby perch and repeats the song at 3:38.

recordings.rmk: A selection of calls (piqued sounds of several types) made by a Song Thrush. Most of these calls were inaudible to the human ear. At least one pair were in an area where the recorder was hidden.  Other Song Thrushes were also nearby and the general level of activity - with courtship song being exchanged between rivals - suggested an edgy atmosphere. Hence, the level of agitation captured in this recording seems to equate with a Song Thrush in an animated mood.
More than ten birds singing in a scrub.

This recording is unedited apart from being cut from a longer recording. The bird I suspect was in a Silver Birch above the recorder (Olympus LS11, built in mics) which was on short tripod (3 inches) on lawn. Time was late morning approximately (I just set the recorder and left it).

During the winter of 2016-2017 a Greenshank wintered on the island of Inishbofin, west of County Galway. During March, I noticed that one Song Thrush on the island had incorporated Greenshank flight calls into its repertoire. At the time, I tried but failed to get a good recording of the Song Thrush impersonating the Greenshank. By early April my luck changed because I inadvertently recorded the impersonation in the background of a Wheatear recording [XC363484]. Time stamps on the latter recording pinpoint the impersonation in three places. By May, it was obvious that the impersonation had spread among several Song Thrushes (at least ten have incorporated the Greenshank impersonation). Moreover, I have heard the same copy from a Blackbird (once) and a Robin (once). On this recording, copies of Greenshank flight call are at 0:46, 1:52, 2:20, 3:12, 3:59, 4:23, 4:58 and 5:10. As a fortunate accompaniment, a Starling starts vocalising from about the fourth minute onwards and it adds impersonations of other species. For example, Herring Gull at 4:12, 5:04, and 5:16; Lapwing at 4:44, 4:51 and 5:18; Curlew at 5:12 and 5:23. Goldfinch calls are at the very start and end of the clip. Interestingly, I have not heard a Starling copy the Song Thrush's impersonation of Greenshank, despite most of the island's population now indulging in the mimicry! Recordings of another (or possibly two different birds) Song Thrush on Inishbofin also imitating a Greenshank are here: XC373276, XC373277.
Low juniper scrub with scattered deciduous bushes
The bird begins to song at 05:20 with only very little interruptions during the day. A very loud song, an energy without limits!
